title: If the 1st mortgage is not greater than the value of the home, but 1st+2nd together are, how can ch. 13 help?
question: The value of my home is more than what I owe on the property, but combining the 1st + the second they are more than the value. If I file ch. 13 providing I have employment, can it still effect the second loan. I am not being foreclosed on but am being threatened by the bank on my line of credit. I owe less than $500.00 on the second, but 3 months behind on the first, and still making monthly payments on the first. I want to know if ch. 13 can help my situation, thanks.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Employment
answers:
I have successfully filed many lien strips on real estate. If it is your primary residence and the liens only cover the real estate, then the only question is whether the house is worth more than the first. If so, then the second is secured and cannot be removed. If the house is worth even one dollar over the payoff on the first, the second is secured and cannot be changed.

There seems to be a contradiction in the first sentence of your question. I will assume that what you mean is that your house is worth more than the balance of the first mortgage but less than the value o9 You can "strip off" your second or junior mortgage (i.e., the court must value the residence and void the lien created by the 2nd mortgage) in Chapter 13 only if the value of the house is less than the balance of the first mortgage. If the value of your house is even $1 more than the balance of the 1st mortgage then you cannot strip off the 2nd mortgage. The 2nd mortgage has to be totally unsecured (no value above the balance of the first mortgage). It sounds like the benefit to you of a C13 would be to allow you to pay the 3 months you are behind on your first mortgage in the C13 plan over 36 to 60 months with no interest. You would have to also pay the late payments on the 2nd mortgage in the plan unless you can strip off the second mortgage.

The way I interpret the question it sounds like you are saying that there is enough value in the property so that the 1st is wholly secured but the 2nd is partially secured. Under those circumstances you can not strip the second. It must be wholly unsecured to strip.

Without knowing all of your finances it is hard to say. The portion of your second that is undersecured may be made unsecured through a lien strip under Section 506 of the bankruptcy code. See a bankruptcy attorney to discuss this.
